text:
Neurodiversity has to do with cognitive function. It's how the brain works and processes things. It includes everything from autism to dyslexia to adhd.

It also includes conditions like epilepsy and even cognitive issues brought on by head trauma or prolonged drug usage.

One of the weird things I experience is suddenly and randomly being hit by a wave of loss and/or nostalgia.

@EbonyJadeHilton In the ED, we only used ketamine for weight-based, rapid-induction, short-duration sedation in children (e.g., for reduction of joint dislocations). We specifically avoided using it in adults due to the likelihood of inducing a dysphoric state.

8+2=10 
10+4=14

text: (6) This isn't even about calling it 'neurodiversity' or 'inclusivity'. It's moving away from labels and calling it 'learning' in an educational environment, and 'working' in a working environment. The more we label things as 'others who aren't 'us'' the more we diminish them.

text:
☂️It’s not in my nature to do as I’m told without question.
☂️I need to know what, where and why before my brain will (or won’t) comply.
☂️I have an interest based nervous system, rather than the urgent/important processes of Neurotypical people. 
#ADHD #Neurodiversity

@amandadeibert Then: There was no such word as neurodiversity. I seldom understood things happening around me. I was always in trouble at school, but never knew why, and was paddled often.

Now: I believe it made me a much more capable instructor – able to view things from many points of view.

text:
the weirdest part is being perfectly cordial with said people for years

but between being a third culture kid & not-conventionally-read QTIPOC,

neurodiversity is just another layer of me going “I wish you well and love seeing you happy”, but apparently a gap not worth bridging.

text:
sad when you realise how often social groups close away cos “you’re a bit weird/not normal, are you”,

or worse still close away silently with their in-jokes and you realise you would’ve loved the friendship but not those trivialities anyway,

it’s late-identified neurodiversity.

"15% of the population is neurodiverse."

text:
#LivingWithADHD THREAD 12/

HYPERACTIVITY
I'm filled with an explosive but chaotic energy

Pros - I can offer huge passion & energy to things I enjoy
Cons - Life can be exhausting. I can't sit still. I am always fidgeting. I am clumsy. I talk too much

#ADHD #Neurodiversity

text:
#LivingWithADHD THREAD 11/

BOUNDARIES
I don't understand normal social rules & 'boundaries'. 

Pros - I am authentic, people get to know me quickly. I make very close friends.
Cons - I often get into trouble for 'inappropriate' conversations or behaviours

#ADHD #Neurodiversity
tokenized_text: <hashtag> living with adhd </hashtag> <allcaps> thread </allcaps> <number> / <allcaps> boundaries </allcaps> i do not understand normal social rules & ' boundaries ' . pros - i am authentic , people get to know me quickly . i make very close friends . cons - i often get into trouble for ' inappropriate ' conversations or behaviours <hashtag> adhd </hashtag> <hashtag> neurodiversity </hashtag>

text:
#LivingWithADHD THREAD 10/

IMPULSIVE
I'm very impulsive, I speak and act quickly based on gut feelings

Pros - I speak my mind & take scary opportunities 
Cons - I can't wait my turn. I say things I shouldn't. I interrupt people. I can't resist temptation.

#ADHD #Neurodiversity
tokenized_text: <hashtag> living with adhd </hashtag> <allcaps> thread </allcaps> <number> / <allcaps> impulsive </allcaps> i am very impulsive , i speak and act quickly based on gut feelings pros - i speak my mind & take scary opportunities cons - i can not wait my turn . i say things i should not . i interrupt people . i can not resist temptation . <hashtag> adhd </hashtag> <hashtag> neurodiversity </hashtag>

text:
#LivingWithADHD THREAD 8/

AWARENESS OF TIME
I have no awareness of the passage of time

Pros - I will give a lot of time & attention when I'm engaged
Cons - I forget meetings. I can't prioritise. I'm always late. I get 'caught' in time sinks (eg Twitter!)

#ADHD #Neurodiversity
tokenized_text: <hashtag> living with adhd </hashtag> <allcaps> thread </allcaps> <number> / <allcaps> awareness of time </allcaps> i have no awareness of the passage of time pros - i will give a lot of time & attention when i am engaged cons - i forget meetings . i can not prioritise . i am always late . i get ' caught ' in time sinks ( eg twitter ! ) <hashtag> adhd </hashtag> <hashtag> neurodiversity </hashtag>

text:
#LivingWithADHD THREAD 7/

ORGANISATION
I am chaotic & disorganised. I struggle with schedules & deadlines

Pros - I am comfortable with change & can respond quickly in a crisis
Cons - I can be very confusing to work with. I'm messy & always losing things.

#ADHD #Neurodiversity

text:
#LivingWithADHD THREAD 6/

SENSITIVITY
I am very sensitive to people and sounds. Crowds and loud noise make me anxious and grumpy.

Pros - I can notice things others do not
Cons - I am often jumpy and overwhelmed by people and noise

#ADHD #Neurodiversity

#LivingWithADHD THREAD 5/

SCATTER BRAINED
My mind is always whirring with different thoughts & topics

Pros - I am very creative and make connections that many do not
Cons - I cannot stay 'on topic' or follow rules. Others can find me difficult to follow. 

#ADHD #Neurodiversity

text:
#LivingWithADHD THREAD 4/

FOCUS
I only have two modes of concentration; super extremely focussed and super extremely distracted.

Pros - I am incredibly productive when doing things I enjoy 
Cons - I am USELESS at things I don't enjoy

#ADHD #Neurodiversity

text:
#LivingWithADHD THREAD 3/

FEELINGS
My feelings are overwhelming. They soak into everything I do. 

Pros - I am very open, warm, expressive, & empathic 
Cons - I don't trust my feelings. I am 'full on'. I can't function when low.

#ADHD #Neurodiversity

text:
#LivingWithADHD THREAD 2/

MOOD
My mood is a roller-coaster. I swing from very cheerful to very miserable to very angry in minutes. 

Pros - I forgive & move on very quickly 
Cons - I can be confusing & alarming to others

#ADHD #Neurodiversity

text:
#LivingWithADHD THREAD 1/

text:
I've come to understand that any opposition to neurodiversity comes from two ends:

a) those who worry expanding the definitions of ND will threaten these institutions

b) those who worry that doing so will take away the accomodations given to them by those institutions

text: @Marxist100 There’s a difference between gen disabilities and neurodiversity, which can also be a disability. People w/BPD like other neurodivergents, have differences in brain structures and functions in a way other MI sufferers may not show. Hence why it’s sometimes considered ND.

text:
Okay folks, let's talk about bipolar. It's something that's stigmatised, and doesn't get anywhere near as much visibility as some other forms of neurodiversity. 

I have Bipolar II, and I've all the signs that I'm experiencing a hypomanic episode right now.

Thread 👇

text:
@MiguelNouhan @Jessiejames1113 @ACTBrigitte One example is that the neurodiversity community likes to claim autism is the future of human evolution, and claims it's because they're cold and logical.

Yet they also hate being called robotic, and claim that they actually feel too many emotions yet can't communicate them.

text: I couldn’t put words together, I just kept drawing a blank, pausing for far longer than I should to remember the words for things. It was as if a dense marine layer had settled into the farthest reaches of my memory, obscuring words from view, rendering me mute. #neurodiversity

text: I could always write better than I could ever talk. Linguistics, etymology, the power of words have been a huge influence on my life. Which is why the other day I was mortified that I couldn’t remember the words for simple items or phrases to save my life. #neurodiversity

text:
the term neurodivergent is a VERY broad term. it's meant to be that way, just like neurodiversity is. 

neurodivergent simply means having a brain that functions differently from "normal." this can be innate, or differences stemming from outside forces, such as trauma.
tokenized_text: the term neurodivergent is a <allcaps> very </allcaps> broad term . it ' s meant to be that way , just like neurodiversity is . neurodivergent simply means having a brain that functions differently from " normal . " this can be innate , or differences stemming from outside forces , such as trauma .

text:
I'm going to use the terms "normal" and "typical" a lot. please know this describes societal standards. 

neurodiversity is the simple biological fact that some human brains are different than others. the fact that there is a "norm" and brains that differ from that.

a. Not as the market views it! People rush to celebrate neurodiversity when it leads to market rewards, e.g. the autistic detail-oriented software tester. But not every divergence from being neurotypical is as economically useful.

When you accept your limitations you become free.

Painful journey to freedom

26. I used to think "mental illness" was something you went to therapy & took meds for, to be normal.

text:
How To Make Your Social Movement More Inclusive of Neurodiversity by @E_Kess

1. Don’t expect everyone to do the same amount of work.

2. Accept people who are flaky, and find ways to include them.

3. Use diverse forms of communication.

4. Don’t over-pack your schedule.
